WRITING.TITLE: I feel like "You're the Worst" is a completely different show than it was in season one and I want to hear other people's thoughts about it.
WRITING.TEXT:
[SPOILERS]
I adored this show when it first came out. Then, when Gretchen's depression surfaced (as someone who also suffers from mental illness) I thought the show was being really brave and thought provoking.
Still, as time went on, I went from constantly laughing at this show and loving the characters, to feeling like I'm slowly watching people I care about destroy their lives. Even in the beginning of Gretchen's illness I loved Lindsay and Edgar's zany side-antics, but now even their storylines have gotten really dark. (I also completely hate Edgar's girlfriend and the fact that Lindsay got back with her husband and is basically in the same place she started in at the beginning of the show, except pregnant.)
I'm slowly starting to dislike all the characters. Maybe the show is THAT meta though, and I'm supposed to slowly start hating everyone? Thoughts?
EDIT: I'm not really saying the show got *worse* I think the writing and character development is still very complex, but I am enjoying it far less than I used to. Maybe it's just too *real* for me? I'm not sure... still trying to process how I feel.

I feel like everyone here is saying "because he was the rightful king." That's not what OP asked. He asked why people *love* him. I agree he is the rightful king but I also thing he is a fucking scumbag just like almost everyone else in Westeros.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone else feel like "You're the Worst" has had a big dip in quality writing, or at least massively changed direction? (Spoilers)

So the Taco Cabana near my house does mariachi music super loud twice a week and people go there and dance and it's always packed on those nights. It's a lot of fun and I like their food and stuff. We live a stone's throw away from Mexico so the population here is like 97% Mexican American. It's also the largest military instillation in the USA.
Still, two years in a row, Taco Cabana's mariachi days have fallen on 9/11 and I bitched about it both times because it just felt super shitty to me. Several of my friends have told me that it's not really a big part of Mexican culture to "observe" (or whatever) 9/11. That pisses me off too, because they are Americans who want to be treated as such (as they should be!) and yet they claim "not my culture" when I express frustration at a large corporation throwing a rip-roaring party on 9/11.
It just bugs me and nobody seems to understand why. They are just like "calm down, who ducking cares?" I'm not saying everyone needs to walk around with their heads down acting sad but just hearing the music and seeing the partying feels garish and disrespectful to me. I'm not even THAT patriotic. I'm not offended when people choose not to stand for the pledge or national anthem. Whatever, you do you. I wouldn't even be as upset if someone threw a party at their house on 9/11. It just feels shitty to me when a huge company doesn't give enough of a fuck to post-pone their bi-weekly party for this.
For real. My dog died last month and I'm still heartbroken. It's normal to still be heartbroken and all and I wouldn't change it if I could but that shit hurts.

I didn't say cats don't mourn. They certainly do. They don't mourn for as long as we do and not the way we do. If a mom cat loses her baby or the baby is adopted out, they get over it after a while, whereas if someone stole my daughter I'd never get over it. The op of this thread is insinuating that months, if not years later, the mother still goes to the grave to mourn. Heck no techno.
Maybe if a cat grew up with an owner or another pet for the majority of its life it might mourn longer or not be the same but I'm not buying OPs story in this case. Not a bit.

I bought a deck and learned to give readings over the period of a few years. I never believed it but it was a really fun thing to do at parties and people swore up and down that the readings were accurate. Agreed, but nobody ever would have known because I was so compliant in the abuse. It took me years to even realize I was being abused in the first place because he never physically hit me. That doesn't excuse how he acted it just exposed how in the dark I was about it.

He started accusing me of cheating on him or being sneaky. He had a reason, one by one, to hate all my friends, convinced me they were trying to break us up and isolated me from them. Then he did the same with my family. It was a self fulfilling prophesy because after he did that they really did try and get me to leave him, but by then I was brainwashed.
I was slowly given less and less freedom over a long period of time until I wasn't allowed to go grocery shopping, go to a laundromat or leave the house. Even my internet access was limited through constant monitoring. Little changes over time that prevented big red flags from going off. Like a frog in the pot that doesn't notice the water getting hot until it's boiling.
He never physically hit me but by the end he was knocking food out of my hands, throwing things past me and hitting walls next to my head and I knew it was a precursor to physical abuse. What got me out was our daughter.
She had no clean clothes and so I demanded to be allowed to go to the laundromat. He consented because he was too lazy to do it himself. Once I got there he demanded I come home and when I refused he said he left our one year old at home alone. I rushed home and he had been bluffing, but for me the writing was on the wall. He could torture me all he wanted but I would not allow him to effect my daughter's life.
The next day I left without permission to go wash clothes *with* my baby. He texted, threatening to kill himself if I didn't go home. I told him to do it and then called the cops and had them do a welfare check on him. They arrested him because he had warrants for unpaid traffic tickets. I went home and changed the locks and never let him in again. After almost a week of sleeping outside in the desert behind the house, he got the message and left. It was about a year before he stopped trying to "win me back" though.

A little under a month.
So I used to have a tricky shoulder that would come out of socket when he and I first started dating. About three weeks after we started dating, we were laying in bed after sex and he whispered in my ear. "I think I love you."
I was not expecting that and whipped around so quick that I lost my balance and fell out of bed and dislocated my shoulder. So I was screaming in pain and he was freaking out because he didn't know what to do and I finally got it back in socket.... And that ladies is how I got out of saying "I love you" without anyone getting their feelings hurt.
No I didn't do it on purpose but it bought me a few days with which to search my feelings and resize I loved him too.

WRITING.TITLE: When does the hyper start?
WRITING.TEXT:
I rescued my puppy from the kill shelter about two weeks ago. He is a German Shepherd Labrador Retriever mix. I don't know exactly how old he is but he is about 14 lbs right now.
He sleeps all day and wrestles a bit with our Australian cattle dog/terrier mix but all he really seems to want to do is sleep on me. Did I luck out or is the hurricane coming later?
The vet says he is in perfect health, he eats a ton and eliminates normally so I don't things is sick.

I did a lot of hard thinking about cutting him out of her life in the begging beginning because I wanted to spare her the pain. I knew a lot of kids growing up who didn't know their fathers at all because their mothers cut all ties. Many of them almost worshipped the *idea* of their fathers and resented the hell out of their moms. Many did not consider that perhaps the mom had a good reason.
I have a friend who is a family lawyer and he also told me that the courts won't legally take away his right unless he is dangerous. He's an ass but he isn't dangerous. I don't think he would fight me if I did it illegally because he can't afford to take me to court but then things get nasty and that can be traumatic for her too.
Like I said, we are moving to another city soon and he won't bother following so I think this problem is about to solve itself.

Married him anyway. We are divorced now, not because he was the only person I was with but because I was conflicted for very good reasons.
I don't know your situation and cold feet is normal, but don't ignore strong doubts if that is what they are.

Is it possible to have her go back to work and hire someone to watch your child while you both are at work?
I lost my job about a year ago and have since been working from home as a freelance writer. Work is hard to come by and I've slowly been spiraling into a deep depression. I did not realize how much I based my self worth on my work.
Being home all day, every day with any child, let alone one with extra struggles, sounds very depressing. It sounds like a dream to a lot of people who work full time, to get to stay home all day with the kid(s) but in reality, for many, becomes soul crushing.
Most people thrive on accomplishment and if you are not getting out of the house every day and accomplishing things, however menial and inconsequential they may be, it becomes easy to spiral into depression until *nothing* matters. Tell me, were things better when she was still working?

I have (had) two friends in AA and both have been sober for years now. I stopped hanging out with one do them. One just doesn't drink. The other won't shut up about how evil Alcohol is and won't stop judging the shit out of everyone who drinks even the slightest bit of it.
I'm happy she is sober and she needed to get sober. That being said, I liked her better when she was drinking because she was not such an insufferable ass. Still, her life isn't about making me happy, it's about her being healthy. I'm happy for her and she can stay healthy and sober without me. I'd never trade her sobriety for our old friendship back.

I finally made a deal breaker list with every petty thing I could think of on it and swore I'd not compromise. I didn't and when I finally found the guy who met all my qualifications, it was/is the best relationship I've ever been in.

He plays with our daughter's heart. She's seven.
He sees her about 1-2 times a year. Christmas and her birthday (half of the time). He is allowed to see her whenever he wants and we live in the same city. He still only sees her once or twice a year and I suspect it's because his parents ask where she is on Christmas or her birthday, not because he cares at all.
He sees her just often enough to make it really hurt. She adores him. After she sees him, she cries because she misses him and wants to see him more. This goes on for months until she finally hardens her heart and then it's about time for him to rip the wound open and see her again. I wish he would just decide to either be involved or abandon her altogether instead of constantly wounding her.
I thought about just not allowing him to see her anymore but I'm not going to be the one my daughter blames for keeping her and her dad apart. She has to realize he's a dick on her own. The second she tells me she doesn't want to see him anymore I'll oblige but not before that. Luckily were moving soon so I figure after that, he won't bother to travel to see her.
One time he asked to see her out of the blue. I asked him why once he brought her home, you know, just casually because it's really out of character for him. Maybe he was finally missing her? No. He said he took our daughter with him on a first date with a women he knew who liked kids because he thought it would help grease the wheels and show her he was a good dad. I was furious.
I don't hate him for the seven times I caught him cheating when we were together. I don't hate him for the psychological abuse. I don't hate him for making me work two jobs while going to school full time and having to do all the housework so he could play video games all day and do nothing else. I don't hate him for the endless nights crying myself to sleep or the way he isolated me from my family. To hate him for Those things would mean there were still fucks to give about our relationship. I have no fucks for that. do however have a lot of fucks to give about my daughter.
I 100% agree with you but in also curious how many children you have.

WRITING.TITLE: Have any of you grown up with mothers who swear? Did it mess you up?
WRITING.TEXT:
So, I'm a total potty mouth. I have a seven year old daughter and instead of not swearing around her, I just taught her what certain words are "grown up" words, so she doesn't swear at all (Yet!) but I still do. I've been told that expecting this to work in the long term is a pipe dream and I respect that viewpoint.
I have an English degree. It's my opinion that words are mostly about how you use them. There are no "bad" words. Telling someone they are worthless can be just as hurtful as calling them a fuck-head. It's all about how you use your words. In a perfect world, if my seven year old stubbed her toe and screamed "fuck!" I would not care. If she said "fuck you mom" I'd be furious. It's about how you use a word and not if (to me).
Still, I realize the real world does not work that way so I've banned my daughter from swearing. So far so good. When she gets older and learns to use discretion I think I can teach her about the right setting to swear in and about how to use swear words in the right context. I never swear at work or in the wrong setting, but you bet your ass I swear at home.
I've been wondering if any of you grew up with a mom (or even a dad) who swears and turned out fine. I'm open to my mind being changed if need-be.
EDIT: I guess the reason I'm asking is I've seen threads about people who felt scarred from their parents swearing *at* them and though I've never sworn at my kid, I've sworn *about* stuff.
Ex: "sweetie, please clean your room there is shit all over the floor."
"Jeez! Your teacher gave you so much fucking homework!"
"That girl making fun of your shoes sounds like an asshole and you need to not listen to her. Your shoes are fucking gorgeous and that should not even matter. What matters is who you are as a person and she sounds like a shitty person."

Hahaha you have a great imagination. That would be a great story. Also, my fianc and I have been through some REALLY hard stuff together and remained rock solid and you cant put a price on that. I didn't see the point of risking the unknown and leaving a great thing. Also, when I met my fianc my daughter was two and now she is seven so she considers him her father. It's just not worth it for so many reasons.

Story time
In 8th grade I moved to a new city and went to public school for the first time after being homeschooled and made a total ass of myself on the first day because I had no social skills. I was also really really fat and that never helps you make friends in middle school. There was one boy who said I seemed like a pretty cool chick and was nice to me. He was really short and skinny and nerdy.
I found out later that day that we rode the same bus and he lived a few houses down the street from me. We became best friends. We played in the desert behind out houses and built forts. My mom used to joke and say we would get married one day and we both gagged at the idea. His dream was to grow up and be a soldier AND a lawyer and I wanted to be a published writer AND a teacher. (Crazy kids and their big dreams right?)
He went off to military school the following year and we missed each other horribly. Still, we played video games online and would write to each other. A year later my family moved again. We stayed in contact, but over the years it dwindled to maybe an email a year. We both grew up. He joined the army and served two tours, one in Iraq and one in Afghanistan. We both got married and had daughters. We both got divorced. I decided to go back to college and moved to the town we had first met in. He lived elsewhere by then though. Over a year after I had moved there, I ended up running into him at a grocery store and my heart stopped. He was 6'2" and built like a tank, but beside that, he was still my best friend from 8th grade. I had lost weight and was slim and fit myself. I was dating someone pretty seriously at the time and so was he. nothing romantic happened but my boyfriend and I had him over for dinner to catch up. He was in town visiting his parents.
Time passed and the boyfriend and I broke up. Found out my friend was going to be in town soon after. We decided to hang out and we both were drinking. He ended up spilling his guts about getting PTSD from the war and how he just got out of a bad relationship. One thing lead to another and we were ripping into each other like animals. Over a decade of this hidden lust that neither of us had fully acknowledged to ourself. We had sex all night and it was *insanely* good.
I was basically instantly infatuated with him but he had just gotten out of a long relationship and didn't live there so I understood when he casually mentioned the next morning that he didn't want to be in a relationship with anyone for a while. It hurt a little, (ok maybe a lot..) but I was an expert at acting casual. I left that afternoon and decided to join a dating web page because being with him made me realize I was lonely. I met my soon-to-be husband a week after the night I spent with my friend. About six months after we had slept together I got a call from my friend basically confessing his love for me and telling me we were meant to be together. It broke my heart because that was all I ever wanted but I was in love with my boyfriend so I made the decision to stay and I've never regretted it. I'm going to marry the man I'm with now. He is wonderful.
My friend will always be my "what if" though. The one who never quite was...
Side note: He finishes law school this year and I finish getting my masters In Education. I also published my first book last year. I guess we both secretly always knew what we wanted. Just never got the timing right.
I'm basically in the exact same situation you are now. I'm with a wonderful man and I have a good life. I just wish I could love myself more.
